title: How does one master analog electronics? - Quora
tags: Bachelor of Technology in Electronics and Communications Engineering

response.answer_text: Listen, I have some advice that you might find hard to digest, but here it goes: Open the window, take your Boylestad and Milliman-Halkias, and toss them out. The problem with the Analog Syllabus of today is that it goes in reverse order, starting from diodes and junctions, and ending at Operational Amplifiers. It's like starting with Shakespear and ending with ABCD. Look carefully at the book in the image below:  This book is Microelectronic Circuits, by Sedra and Smith. If you truly wish to learn Analog, this shall be your holy book for the next six month. Start with Op Amps. If possible, master 2-port networks from a good Network Theory book even before that. Then, proceed to MOSFET, and then eventually make your way first to diode and then to BJT. I would also advice you to read first two pages of the chapter on BJT from the book on Electron Devices by Streetman and Banerjee. Follow this course of action, and you will do well.

Hi… By knowing How Resistor Capacitor and Inductor Works.By knowing How Analog industry changed from Vacuum Tube to ULSIBy knowing the power of Amplifier, Use of it.By knowing how discrete components behave depending on Voltage, Ampere and Wattage.By knowing the Impedance.By playing with electrons between “Transistor’s Saturation point” to “Cut-off/Breakdown mode”.By converting an Transistor to variable resistor to a switch.By knowing Why Mosfet for switching rather than transistor and why Transistor used as amplifier rather than Mosfet.By knowing why Analog is different than Digital?By loving Analog more than Digital, By showing love to her with time spent regularly, By gaining knowledge and experience when few capacitor busted and few components burned for lack of knowledge…And saying that ohh Analog Electronics, you are classic, elegant, beautiful, thanks for giving me enough scope to learn why digital is nothing but hidden Analog electronics. :)) Regards, SaV
